From personal experience in home insurance repair, understanding the 'deals' on offer is the key.



Loyalty won't save you money- but I've seen thousands of damage claims NOT covered by their PDS, still being approved and repaired.
Most of the time, it is just as a courtesy to long term members.

I still shop around because I can do repairs myself, so I don't need that courtesy.

Keep the excess/deductible very high, read and understand the entire PDS. 
Then determine the Cost v. Coverage that suits the situation.

Most insurers will cover major events anyway (to varying degrees), so the real value is in the fine print.



Eg. You drop a bottle and break a tile on the floor of your shower recess*-


Insurer A: "We will cover the min cost of a tiler (4hrs), and an allowance to find a matching tile ($50), but we can't guarantee a watertight repair,  so we will be cash settling for the above price."

Insurer B: "We have a policy that allows $1500 towards matching materials. We will also allow 4hrs for a tiler.
We will cash settle as above."

Insurer C: "Fuck. Let's find you a motel while we replace your entire bathroom, and provide a warranty for all works undertaken."


*Dependant on relevant building codes and existing construction methods.


 
Insurer A, B and C can be in very similar price brackets, so an instant saving should not be the only criteria when shopping.



Hope this helps.
I was with Geico for 10 years, thought loyalty maybe mattered, but when I found out progressive gave me half the rate for same benefits,  I left.

This is true, was with Geico for over 10 years, I felt loyal to them...for no reason.  Decided to shop around last year and realized we can get the same deal, with a smaller "no name" company, for pretty much half.  And yes, it has a name, just not one that has commercials running everyday.

Esurance has my wife and I at 512 for 6 months liability only on out minivan, we have had them for insurance for 8 years. 

Got some estimates recently and they were all in the $180 range just through the automated system. Went with farmers which was $240 for six months and with the second car in buying today $435.  

Show around and don't be loyal to any company whether it's insurance, your bank, your brand of appliances or your workplace. Always be on the lookout for a better deal/situation.

I was guilty of not paying attention and letting my rates get ridiculously high. Called my insurance and threatened to leave. They told me there was nothing they could do so I left. Magically 3 months later they called and offered me almost half of what my original rate was. Loyalty means nothing to these companies. They're betting on you not leaving because it's too big of a pain.
this is such a nonsense. the cheaper an insurance company is, the more it is possible, that the service sucks and they try to not pay you anything.

If you're switching purely for cost, it means you're always trying to be on the cheapest possible company.  This are not going to end well for you, whoever you use.

I have criteria for companies I use that far exceed base cost.  My government are always on about moving my ISP, utilities, insurance, etc. on comparison sites.

In the UK, the cheapest gas companies all just went bust, pushing their customers onto higher prices because they don't have a sustainable business model once energy prices start to rise.  That's a ton of hassle, and because of complete lack of investment in their services.

I want a company that supplies what I want, fucks off, leaves me alone, stays around for a long time and doesn't go trying to con me.  That usually means NOT the cheapest company at all.

I'm far from being a capitalist, I'm a no-hassleist.  My only ISP is actually a 4G stick that I manage myself and change SIMs if people don't perform.  I've changed once in 4 years, and not to the cheapest company - and that was because the company failed to inform me that they had better deals that I could be put onto with them, they tried to profit from my loyalty.  So rather than go to the cheaper package with them, I paid more and moved to a far more up-front and honest company.

My car insurance I change almost every year because it rises for absolutely no reason - I've had no accidents and other companies will insure me cheaper.  But I have a blacklist of insurance companies who will always give me cheaper insurance, but who I refuse to use.

Loyalty isn't rewarded to customers.  Don't think it ever is.  But a company's loyalty to me is rewarded - I stay being a customer and will pay more for an equivalent service than I would pay their competitors.

Basically:  Don't spam me, don't raise prices, don't change the deal (unless it's for the better), don't skimp on services, don't try to profiteer.

I actually like companies without in-person or on-the-telephone customer service.  They seem to work so much better.  And companies that DON'T contact me with random sales material.

You've got a new cheaper deal for existing customers?  Great, why do I need to "switch" to it?  That means the deal is different.  Just lower my price automatically and then tell me that.  I'll be over the moon about that.  Or give me more for my money and tell me that.

That's how almost all the companies I use work, and I'm loyal to them because of it.

And hardly any company I use is the "cheapest".
I don't live in the US but where I live, any savings you might get from switching are usually negligible and not worth the bother.
This. Other people’s played us good
The biggest issue I have with this is the fact that you can’t easily have your personal details deleted from each company as you move providers
Well, there's avoiding the hassle of finding a new one.

This isn't bad advice per se, but there are 2 important things to remember. 1, many insurance companies give a discount to new customers in an effort to entice you to leave your current company, but then your rate could increase significantly at your first renewal. 2, many insurance companies give you a lower rate based on how long you were with your previous company. The idea is, if you were a loyal customer with your previous company for a long time, maybe you'll be loyal to this company too; and also, again, to entice you to switch companies.  

So here's an example scenario. Let's say your rate with company A is $100 per month and you've been with them for 5 years. Company B offers you $90 per month. So you think, fuck it, it's cheaper so I might as well. 6 months later, your renewal rate is $150 per month. What the hell? That's a huge increase. It is what it is, they say, rates change over time (this is true). Well, you say, I'm going back to company A, they only charged me $100 per month with only small fluctuations each term. You get a quote from company A for $180 per month. Guess what? Now you've only been with your company for a single term, which is usually 6 months. You're not a good customer anymore, so you don't get the best rate.  

tldr: Only switch insurance companies if the savings are significant. You could save money in the short term and screw yourself in the long term.

Work for State Farm. 
The benefits seem good at first, but actually the longer you stay with a company the better your price will be long term. 
This normally comes in the form of a 3 year, 5 year, 10 year, 20 year concept. A lot of companies will also give accident forgiveness around the 10 year mark. Which could save you a lot of money in the long run. 
You just never know when rates will go up or down. They depend on you a lot as an individual. 
People are rated on what’s called the CRI or Customer Rating Index. Credit score, loans, driving history, time being licensed, etc. 
It’s worth shopping around but being loyal to a company can pay out big in the long run. 
It’s a cost analysis for each person as an individual. There are different insurance companies for everyone. Some have better pricing for people with accidents and tickets.

In some states there is a significant advantage to being loyal to my homeowners insurance company. If you have been a customer for 5 years, your policy cannot be canceled if you file a hurricane claim. Less than 5 years, you can be dropped based on a hurricane filing.

I’m not going to stand up for faceless corporations, but there is an advantage: most of them have rules about how often you can renegotiate prices, and they know how many times you’ve changed companies and will price you accordingly.
